Review Rational design of Fe-M-N-C based dual-atom catalysts for oxygen reduction electrocatalysis Zhechen Fan a Hao Wan a Hao Yu a Junjie Ge a b * a School of Chemistry and Materials Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, Anhui, China School of Chemistry and Materials Science University of Science and Technology of China Hefei Anhui 230026 China School of Chemistry and Materials Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, Anhui, China b Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Liaoning 116023 China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author Fe-N-C based single-atom catalysts (SACs) with isolated Fe atoms dispersed on nitrogen-doped carbon matrix have achieved sustained attention for oxygen reduction reaction due to their great potential in replacing the Pt based noble catalysts in terms of catalytic activity. To further trigger the intrinsic activity of Fe-N-C, Fe based dual-atom catalysts (DACs, i.e., Fe-M-N-C) have been intensively studied, which confer the catalysts with readily tunable geometric configurations, electronic structures, thereby tailored catalytic properties. In this review, current progress on the rational design of Fe-M-N-C based DACs for enhanced oxygen reduction catalysis is summarized. Firstly, the ORR mechanisms on DACs are discussed where the second metal atoms can function through synergistic effect and/or modulation effect to promote the intrinsic catalytic activity. Moreover, the currently available synthetic approaches, characterization techniques and computational methods are systematically reviewed to aid the investigation of DACs. Then, DACs are classified into marriage-type and conjunct-type based on the interaction between metal atoms, whose properties are discussed at length with the atomic configuration. At last, the main challenges of Fe-M-N-C based DACs are summarized and some appealing directions towards highly efficient and stable energy applications are provided for their further enhancement. Graphical Abstract This review has summarized the current progress on the rational design of Fe-M-N-C based dual-atom catalysts for enhanced oxygen reduction catalysis, including the mechanism, preparation, characterization, calculation and atomic configuration. The main challenges and appealing directions are also provided for the development of highly efficient and stable energy applications. Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Fe based catalyst Dual-atom catalyst Catalytic activity Atomic configuration 1 Introduction The lack of a cost-effective replacement for Pt catalyst towards oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) has greatly hampered the wide commercialization of the technology. Therefore, searching for viable cheap alternatives to Pt is a topic attracting intensive efforts [1–7]. Until now, the alternative materials for ORR are fundamentally restricted by either a low catalytic efficiency or a limited lifetime. Among the different type of catalysts, pyrolyzed metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) based catalysts have been widely studied owing to the well-defined structure of M-N x sites and abundant surface defects of carbon substrates, which are responsible for the favorable characteristics of catalytic activity and thermodynamic stability [8–14]. Over the past decades, rapid progress has been made in activity optimization and mechanism research of these catalysts. It has been revealed that ORR activity of M-N-C catalysts with different metal atom centers follow the Sabatier principle, in which a modest M–O binding strength exhibits the best catalytic activity in the volcano-shaped curves [15–20]. Notably, Fe-N-C based catalysts with Fe-N x sites are located at a considerably high position near the top of inverted parabola, and have been consequently proved to be one of the most potential candidates among a series of M-N-C catalysts [21–26]. Nevertheless, Fe-N-C catalysts are still unable to replace commercial Pt/C, mainly hampered by the following drawbacks. First, like most of single-atom catalysts (SACs), the metal loadings of these catalysts reported are relatively low to avoid aggregation of metal atoms owing to the high surface energy, resulting in inadequate active sites [27–33]. Second, the activity of Fe-N-C still fall short of expectations owing to its too strong Fe–O bond [19,20,31]. Third, SACs have only an isolated metal atom as the active site, make it difficult to optimize the catalytic activity by adjusting the adsorption configuration of reactant molecules, such as top and bridge model of O2 adsorption in ORR [34–37]. Forth, Fe-N-C based catalysts have been plagued by the stability issues, especially in the acidic media [38–43]. The deterioration of Fe-N x active sites originates from several mechanisms, including protonation of nitrogen groups [44–46], demetallation [47–49] and carbon oxidation [43,50–52]. Worse still, Fenton reaction involving Fe2+ and H2O2 generates aggressive reactive oxygen species (ROS), thereby aggravating the corrosive reaction on carbon matrix [43,53]. This intrinsic property of Fe-based catalysts can only be alleviated by minimizing the ROS level. Dual-atom catalysts (DACs) comprised of multiple isolated metal atoms or metal dimers are newly emerging materials as an extension of SACs, and especially their inspiration for Fe-N-C catalysts has achieved rising attention [54–70] (Fig. 1 ). A promising approach to disembarrass Fe-N-C catalysts is the introduction of another isolated atom, forming Fe-M-N x sites supported on carbon matrix (M = the second metal atom), which are known as Fe-M-N-C-based DACs, including Fe-Fe [66,68], Fe-Co [65,71–73], Fe-Ni [74–77], Fe-Cu [78,79], Fe-Zn [80,81], Fe-Mn [82,83], Fe-Pt [84–86], Fe-Ru [87], Fe-Ir [88] and many other atomic couples. The Fe and the other metal center can synergistically provide various possible adsorption sites, break the linear relationships between the adsorption energy towards different oxygen species and potentially catalyze some complex reactions [54,56,89,90]. In addition, the newly entered metal atoms have opportunities to regulate the d-orbital filling states of Fe atom by orbital interactions [36,55–57,91]. Based on the interaction between two metal atom centers, DACs can be classified as marriage-type and conjunct-type dual-atom catalysts. The marriage-type DACs are considered to have two independent single-atom sites which are randomly distributed in unlimited spatial distances. In contrast, the single-atom sites on conjunct-type DACs are usually linked through metal-metal bond or metal-bridge bond such as N, C atoms between adjacent metal atoms [65,74,92–94]. The influence of neighboring metal atoms is able to synergistically tune the electronic properties and catalytic activity of Fe active sites. According to the central atoms, they can be further divided into homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs. Compared with SACs, Fe-M-N-C-based DACs are newly emerging and show a remarkable potential for ORR catalysis. Although many related works have been published, there is still a lack of focused discussion in this filed. Therefore, a comprehensive review is highly desirable to provide a wide scope for the development of DACs. In this review, we have summarized the current progress made over past few years on the different kinds of Fe-M-N-C based DACs (Fig. 2 ). The ORR mechanisms on DACs are highlighted with potential effects of the second metal atoms. Then, the available synthetic approaches, identification techniques and computational methods for DACs are listed. Especially, the properties of two kinds of DACs are discussed in detail through specific examples while the atomic configuration are emphasized. Finally, the main challenges and opportunities are provided to guide the development of DACs. In this way, this review could be inspiring for improving the catalytic performance and propelling the practical application of Fe-M-N-C based DACs. 2 ORR mechanisms on Fe-M-N-C based DACs 2.1 Reaction pathway for ORR In a typical model proposed by Wroblowa et al. [95], ORR in acidic media usually involves a four-electron pathway (Eq. (1)) or a two-electron pathway (Eq. (2)), in which O2 molecules are converted into H2O or H2O2, respectively. Also, the H2O2 from two-electron pathway may undergo a sequential pathway (Eq. (3)) and be further reduced to H2O on another active site. (1) O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O (2) O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2 (3) H2O2 + 2H+ +2e− → 2H2O Apparently, the four-electron pathway of ORR is much favorable owing to its higher energy efficiency and avoidance of pernicious product, H2O2. It has been reported that two kinds of pathways parallelly exist in the Fe-N-C catalysts. Therefore, it counts a lot for the performance of Fe-based catalysts to raise the selectivity for the four-electron reduction [96,97]. To better understand the ORR process, the conversion of O2 to H2O or H2O2 has been further explained at the molecular level. Considering the multiple oxygen intermediates involved, the ORR process can be divided into several reaction steps in detail. The relevant intermediates and steps are illustrated in Fig. 3 . For the four-electron pathway to generate H2O from O2, three possible mechanisms are distinguished by the occasion in which O–O bond breaks. (1) Dissociation pathway: adsorbed O2* directly dissociates into two O*, which obtain proton and electron to form OH* and then H2O (Eqs. (4)–(7)). (2) Associative pathway: O2* firstly binds to a proton to form OOH*, which subsequently conduct O–O bond cleavage to form O* and OH*. The O* and OH* are given proton in succession and reduced to H2O (Eqs. (8)–(11)). (3) 2nd associative pathway: O2* is reduced to OOH* and HOOH* step by step, then breaks into two OH* and eventually forms H2O (Eqs. (12)–(15)). In brief, the O–O bond cleavage occurs in different oxygen species, including O2*, OOH* and HOOH* [9,53]. (1) Dissociation pathway: (4) O2 + * → O2* (5) O2* → O* + O* (6) O* + H+ + e− → OH* (7) OH* + H+ + e− → H2O + * (2) Associative pathway: (8) O2* + H+ + e− → OOH* (9) OOH* → O* + OH* (10) O* + H+ + e− → OH* (11) OH* + H+ + e− → H2O + * (3) 2nd associative pathway: (12) O2* + H+ + e− → OOH* (13) OOH* + H+ + e− → HOOH* (14) HOOH* → OH* + OH* (15) OH* + H+ + e− → H2O + * In the case of (4) two-electron pathway, O2* obtains protons and electrons to form OOH*, and then HOOH*. Eventually, H2O2 molecule is directly released without O–O bond cleavage (Eqs. (16)–(18)). (16) O2* + H+ + e− → OOH* (17) OOH* + H+ + e− → HOOH* (18) HOOH* → H2O2 + * The above pathways all involve species adsorption, electron transfer, proton transfer, bond breaking and formation and species desorption. Therefore, the adsorption and desorption of oxygen species on the active sites is crucial for ORR catalysis, while a modest binding energy is desired. When the binding strength is too weak, the catalytic sites are unable to activate O2 and drive the reduction process. Conversely, too strong binding hampers the removal of oxygen intermediates [20]. In this view, precious metal such as Pt is recognized as ideal ORR catalyst for its best d-band electronic structure among metal elements. The activity of Fe-N-C catalysts is limited by the over-strong Fe–O binding [16,53,98]. Otherwise, for a favorable four-electron pathway, the cleavage of O–O bonds in O2 is ineluctable but usually possesses a high energy barrier. Fe-N-C catalysts conduct an association-predominated mechanism due to the high dissociation barrier of O2 on Fe-N x sites [99,100]. Therefore, the ORR activity of Fe-N-C catalysts can be evaluated from two aspects: alleviating the adsorption energy and wakening O–O bonds. With the introduced second metal atom, Fe-M-N-C based catalysts may realize these targets by synergistic effect and modulation effect. 2.2 Advantages of DACs 2.2.1 Synergistic effect As newly entered isolated metal centers, M-N x sites are naturally considered as supplementary active sites for ORR and break the linear relationships between the adsorption energy of various oxygen species [49,50,52,68]. In addition, M-N x sites may possess catalytic activity for other reactions, such as oxygen evolution reaction [101,102] and radical scavenging reaction [103]. These combinations of distinct active sites may broaden the application of catalysts and settle specific issues during electrocatalysis. Based on many experimental and theoretical investigations, three possible O2 adsorption models on catalysts have been proposed, including end-on model, side-on model and bridge model (Fig. 4 ) [36,57]. These adsorption configuration of initial O2 plays a vital role in cleaving the O–O bond, which is beneficial for four-electron pathway but usually possesses a high energy barrier. For oxygen adsorption on single-atom site Fe-N x , electrons are donated from the 2π orbital of O2 to the empty dz 2 orbital of metal center, and further back donating from partially filled dxy or dyz orbitals of metal center to the 2π* orbital of O2 [104]. Limited by isolated single-atom sites, end-on or side-on models are much likely to occur on the Fe-N-C catalysts. In contrast, the O2 adsorption on dual-atom site Fe-M-N x follows a bridge model, in which two O atoms are respectively bound to a metal atom. In this configuration, the removal of H2O2 intermediates is hindered, and strong σ interaction is generated between O and metal, that activates O2 molecules and weakens O–O bonds [100]. In this way, Fe-M-N-C catalysts with dual-atom sites may change the O2 adsorption configuration and facilitate the four-electron pathway of ORR. 2.2.2 Modulation effect Fe-N-C catalysts possesses relatively appropriate binding strength among a series of nonprecious metal, and Fe-N x are usually defined as preferable active sites for adsorption and catalysis. For some Fe-M-N-C based DACs, only Fe metal centers directly binds and activates O2 and intermediates, while the neighboring M metal centers do not take part in the ORR process. Nonetheless, M metal centers in this configuration environment can slightly modulate the electronic structure of the adjacent Fe atoms, thereby indirectly contributing to the catalytic activity of dual-atom sites [69,84,105]. Similarly, the modulation effect of introduced metal atoms to the activity of Fe-N x sites can be explained by two mechanisms, the alleviation of Fe–O binding strength and the activation of O–O bonds. According to the d-band theory, the d-band center of Fe sites can be regulated by the adjacent metal atoms. When the d-band center in the dual-atom sites shifts down, the excessive adsorption strength of Fe atoms to oxygen species is able to be balanced and the sluggish desorption steps during ORR will be improved. On the other hand, the enriched electrons at Fe sites from neighboring metal atom can be further transferred from the 3d orbitals of transition metal atoms to the 2p anti-bonding orbitals of adsorbed oxygen atoms, thus weakening O–O bonds and accelerating ORR process [92,106–108]. 2.3 Disadvantages of DACs In fact, the reaction steps in ORR are usually more complex, as they involve not only oxygen intermediates but also various factors such as the proton coupled electron transfer and structure variation of electrodes [109,110]. In a Fe-M-N-C based DAC system, the introduction of M metal atoms brings potential new active elements in catalytic sites and even possibly influences the properties of carbon supports during preparation, further confusing the investigation of ORR mechanisms. In addition, the electronic structure and intrinsic activity of the catalytic sites on DACs greatly depends on the relative position of two mental atoms, which tend to randomly dispersed on the carbon matrix. Therefore, how to obtain accurate and stable dual-atom sites on carbon substrate, and how to identify the true active sites of catalysts and clarify their atomic configuration have become the key issues in the study of DACs. To build credible structure-activity relationships, Fe-M-N-C based DACs have raised higher demands for preparation and characterization of catalysts, which will be discussed in depth in following sections. In short, the exact mechanism of ORR on Fe-M-N-C catalysts is still open for discussion. 3 Preparation of Fe-M-N-C-based DACs The unique atomic configuration of DACs provides a good opportunity to further boost the ORR activity of Fe-N-C catalysts. However, given the complexity of introduced metal atoms, higher demands are put on the design and preparation of Fe-M-N-C DACs. There are several key points worth noting before a DAC is obtained. (1) The type of second metal atoms should be chosen rationally according to specific targets. While the second metal centers are introduced as supplementary active sites, some M-N x sites with high intrinsic activity should be considered, such as Co-N x for ORR, Ni-N x for OER and so on. Besides, when attempting to modulate the electronic structure of Fe atoms with a second atom and raise the activity of Fe-N x , the electronegativity, orbital states or other electronic properties of the introduced atoms should be investigated. (2) The adsorption configuration of O2 and electronic modulation effect highly depend on the internuclear distance between two metal species, especially for conjunct-type DACs [80,94,111]. The atomic configuration of dual-atom sites can be predicted and optimized by theoretical calculations and carefully controlled with appropriate synthesis strategies. (3) In the DAC system, the agglomeration of isolated metal atoms become much intractable involving two kinds of probable metal species with different surface energy. Furthermore, the existence of single-atom sites might be inevitable even for well-prepared DACs. But for conjunct-type DACs, it is suggested that the ratio of paired metal atoms is higher than a specific value, such as 70%, so that the configuration of dual-atom sites can reflect the activity of whole catalysts. (4) The relationship between active sites and carbon matrix should also be taken seriously. The micropores of carbon hardly contact with oxygen species, which means metal centers populated in this structure are difficult to work in ORR process [53,112–114]. Therefore, it is also important to regulate the pore structure and active site distribution of Fe-M-N-C catalysts during synthesis. To fabricate a well-designed DAC, approaches enabling precise structural control are in urgent need. In the following section, we review the current strategies for the synthesis of Fe-M-N-C-based DACs. 3.1 Bottom-up strategies Bottom-up strategies means that metal complex molecules are used as metal precursors, from which the metal centers are eventually anchored on the substrates. Different from SACs, DACs necessitate for precise control in the relative position of the metal dimers during synthesis. The metal dimers can be obtained by preselecting metal precursors containing multinuclear configuration. Ye et al. [66] employed the compounds with specific number of Fe atom as precursors, Fe(acac)2, Fe2(CO)9 and Fe3(CO)12, with the encapsulation of the precursor molecules in the cavity of zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) (Fig. 5(a) ). After pyrolysis, these metal precursors are decomposed in to isolated Fe, Fe2 and Fe3 clusters, respectively with aggregation inhibited by the separated cavity of ZIF-8. Similarly, Zhang et al. [70] presented a general synthetic strategy for preparing a series of homonuclear (Fe2, Co2, Ni2, Cu2, Mn2, and Pd2) and heteronuclear (Fe-Cu, Fe-Ni, Cu-Mn, and Cu-Co) DACs (Fig. 5(b)). In this approach, a Robson-type binuclear complex M1M2L with two tunable metal centers is employed as precursor and encapsulated in ZIF-8. DACs with metal dimers are yielded through annealing. Although these approaches with encapsulation-pyrolysis well maintain the initial individual dispersion of metal atoms, most metal centers are incorporated in the bulk of carbon matrix, which may impede their contact with oxygen reactants. Impregnation is among the most widely used synthetic strategies for supported catalysts. It has been proved to be effective to anchor paired metal atoms on carbon matrix under appropriate condition of pyrolysis. Zhang et al. [68] constructed the planar-like Fe2N6 structure by coupling FeN4 sites through thermal migration (Fig. 6(a) ). They firstly prepared carbon matrix by annealing Ketjenblack ECP-600 JD under ammonia atmosphere, and mixed the obtained carbon and hemin in deionized water. After freeze-drying and annealing, the Fe-Fe DAC with Fe2N6 sites was yielded. It is note-worthy that the too-low or too-high annealing temperature resulted in isolated Fe-N sites or aggregated Fe-N nanoparticles, respectively. By means of the interaction between two metal species, diatomic structures with good thermodynamic stability can also be obtained. Zhou et al. [115] found that dual-metal Rh−Fe interbond can act as a chemical facilitator to drive the spontaneous conversion of Fe nanoparticles to single atoms at a relatively low temperature in a top-down process (Fig. 6(b)). Nitrogen-doped carbon was first synthesized, and immersed in ethanol solution of FeCl3. The obtained powder was pyrolyzed at a relatively low temperature of 200 °C under Ar/H2 atmosphere and then repeated the immersion-pyrolysis process with RhCl3 solution. Fe element is initially reduced to Fe nanoparticles, and generates Rh-Fe-N4 dual-atom sites with lower free energy after the introduction of Rh element. The formation of Rh−Fe bond gives extra energy for breaking up metal clusters into isolated atoms, significantly enhancing single-atom dispersion without high-temperature atomization. This discovery reduces the requirement for pyrolysis temperature to stabilize isolated metal atoms and emphasizes the unique potential advantages of DACs in preparation. In a word, impregnation strategies allow to synthesize the carbon materials with well-designed structure and properties in advance, and may expose more active sites on the surface of carbon matrix in DACs. Besides, atomic layer deposition (ALD) is also a promising technique to precisely construct dual-atom sites, which has been proved in preparation of some DACs [116]. Yan et al. [116] reported the preparation of Pt2 dimers on graphene with ALD technique (Fig. 7 ). First, high-temperature thermal reduction and acid oxidation were used to establish isolated anchoring sites for Pt atoms on graphene. In the following step, precursor molecules (MeCpPtMe3) and O2 were alternately exposed at 250 °C to conduct the Pt ALD on graphene support, forming Pt1 single atoms. Next, the second cycle of ALD was performed while the secondary Pt precursor molecule was anchored by the Pt1 single atoms as nucleation site. Lower deposition temperature of 150 °C was applied to avoid metal aggregation and stronger oxidizing regent, O3, was employed to remove the ligand. Finally, Pt2 dimers were constructed on graphene. ALD is a powerful approach to ensure the configuration and uniform distribution of active sites. With appropriate gaseous metal precursor and solid carbon substrate, ALD can be applied to fabricated Fe-M-N-C based catalysts. 3.2 Top-down strategies Top-down strategies utilize the nanoparticles of metal or metal complex as precursor, and drive the migration and dispersion of metal atoms by thermal or mechanical energy, eventually forming isolated metal atoms anchored on the matrix. Some bimetallic compounds can be conveniently employed as precursors for preparation of DACs, while a uniform distribution of two metal species is realized. Wang et al. [117] proposed a synthetic method of Fe-Mn DACs based on the chemical conversion of Mn0.43Fe2.57O4 nanocrystal supracrystals (Fig. 8(a) ). Mn0.43Fe2.57O4 nanocrystals were first synthesized by the heating reaction of manganese oleate, iron oleate and oleic acid in 1-octadecene solution. Then, the as-prepared nanocrystals were pyrolyzed in Ar flow to carbonize the oleic acid ligands, and treated with acid to remove nanocrystal. After further healing treatment with thiourea, a highly ordered mesoporous carbon decorated with Fe-N4 and Mn-N2S2 sites was obtained. Likewise, Li et al. [118] fabricated a Fe-Co DAC with CoFe2O4 substrate (Fig. 8(b)). CoFe2O4 hollow microspheres were prepared by hydrothermal method, and further adsorbed pyrrole monomers under sonication. By adding hydrochloric acid, CoFe2O4 were dissolved and the released Fe3+ initiated the polymerization of pyrrole. The coordination interactions between nitrogen and metal atoms would encase small amounts of isolated Fe or Co inside the polymer. At last, Fe-N4 and Co-N4 sites was achieved after pyrolysis under inert atmosphere. However, how to precisely regulate the internuclear distance to construct dual-atom sites has not yet been resolved for these approaches. Mechanical strategies such as ball-milling are also employed to synthesize catalysts with atomically dispersed metal sites, in which chemical bonds are broken and reconstructed by kinetic energy. Han et al. [119] improved the traditional ball-milling method and proposed an eco-friendly top-down abrasion method for synthesis of SACs (including Fe, Co, Ni and Cu). Bulk metal balls and graphite conducted a ball-milling process under N2 atmosphere. Metal balls provides atomized metal via an atomic-scale abrasion, and transmit kinetic energy to drive mechanochemical reaction. Nitrogen from N2 was incorporated into the unzipped graphite framework and anchored the metal atoms. In this process, no synthetic chemicals and solvents were used and no by-products or waste were generated. Most importantly, this method can be readily scaled up and hold potential to attain high productivity of atomically dispersed catalysts. Through combination of different metal particles, this method might be easily expanded to preparation of Fe-M-N-C-based DACs. But still, one can hardly control the geometry configuration of the dual-atom sites by this method, which make it not suitable for theoretical research. 4 Characterization techniques for Fe-M-N-C based DACs 4.1 Identification of active sites The geometric configuration of dual-atom sites is closely related to their electronic structure and the overall performance of catalysts. The identification of dual-atom sites comprising active metal atoms and adjacent atoms is of significance to further explore the structure-activity relationships of DACs. Although several characterization techniques, including aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and Mössbauer spectroscopy, have been employed to clarify the structure of single-atoms sites, some features of DAC systems should be especially given careful attention, such as the internuclear distance and probable bonding between two metal atoms. 4.1.1 HAADF-STEM The transition metal atoms in Fe-M-N-C based DACs unusually possesses a heavier atomic mass compared with that of C/N atoms in carbon matrix, which enables the metal atoms to be observed by HAADF-STEM. As a characterization method exporting visual images, HAADF-STEM can provide direct evidences for the position and distribution of dual metal sites. In the characterizations of a typical Fe-Fe DAC [120], Fe2-N6-C-o, HAADF-STEM is conducted to confirm the configuration of Fe atoms, which is suggested to exist in a form of dual-atom sites rather than metal clusters. The statistical analysis with about 80 metal sites demonstrates that more than 80% of Fe atoms are involved in bimetallic pairs with an average internuclear distance of 2.37 ± 0.31 Å (Figs. 9(a) and (b) ). Coupled energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping further proves C, N and Fe elements are uniformly distributed throughout the framework of Fe2-N6-C-o catalyst (Fig. 9(c)). When it refers to the heteronuclear DACs, two kinds of metal atoms can be obviously distinguished by the difference in contrast of HAADF-STEM images when their atomic mass is greatly distinctive. For example, isolated Fe and Pt atoms in Fe-Pt DAC [84] are identified by relatively darker Fe dots and brighter Pt dots as marked by the dashed rectangles, with a distance in the range of ca. 5.3 Å (Figs. 9(d)−(f)). However, in most situations, the introduced metal atoms in Fe-M-N-C based DACs possess an approximate atomic number and are hard to tell apart due to the close brightness compared with Fe in images, such as Co, Ni, Mn, Cu and Zn atoms. Therefore, electron energy loss energy spectroscopy (EELS) can be employed as a more effective technology to identify the various elements in DACs. As shown in Fig. 9(g) [71], the electron beam can be focused on a specific microdomain in HAADF-STEM image, and the presence of Fe and Co in the EEL spectrum supports the coexistence of Fe and Co in the dual-atom sites (Fig. 9(h)). EELS mapping images further exhibit that Fe and Co elements are homogenously distributed on the (Fe,Co)/CNT (Fig. 9(i)). Nonetheless, the characterization by HAADF-STEM usually states the geometrical properties of nanoscale local areas on catalysts, and information such as interatomic distance obtained from STEM is unreliable due to the deviation of metal atoms during image acquisition. A universal method in global vision is still desired to present the statistical and average characteristic of DACs. 4.1.2 XAS Synchrotron-radiation XAS has been known as an indispensable technique to clarify the configuration of dual-atom sites. Based on the origin of spectral information, XAS can be further classified into X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) [121–123]. XANES contains spectral information near the absorption edge of XAS, generally reflecting the interaction with matrix and the oxidation states of the target atoms in DACs. Concretely, in XANES, the energy ascribed to absorption edge of isolated metal atoms is usually located between those of the corresponding pure metallic foil and the oxidized reference, implying a mid-valence state of the central metal atoms. For example, the Fe K-edge XANES spectra of (Fe,Co)/CNT [71] is similar to that of FePc, but distinguished from those of Fe foil and Fe2O3, indicating Fe atoms exist in an oxidation state of Fe2+ like FePc, while they are slightly reduced by the metal-metal bonds (Fig. 10(a) ). Besides, EXAFS can be transferred from K space into R space through the Fourier transform, thus considered as an effective tool to probe local structure of the target atoms, unveiling the interatomic distance and coordination number. These parameters are of significance to define the configuration of dual-atom sites. The EXAFS spectra for Fe K-edge of the (Fe,Co)/CNT [71] can be divided into several peaks associated with Fe bonds. Specifically, the peaks at ca. 1.48 and 2.22 Å can be attributed to the Fe–N bond and Fe–Co bond, respectively. The fitting results unravel that the coordination numbers of Fe atoms are approximately 3.4 for N atoms and 1.1 for Co atoms (Figs. 10(b) and (c)). A similar conclusion can also be given from the Co K-edge XANES and EXAFS. Accordingly, the configuration of Fe-Co dual-atom sites can be confirmed in a model of FeCoN6 (Fig. 10(d)). The combination of XANES and EXAFS is regarded as valid method approaching the electronic structure and geometric structure of dual-atom site. 4.1.3 Mössbauer spectroscopy The Mössbauer spectroscopy involves properties of atomic nucleus, including the energy level structure and the locating chemical environment of the nucleus. As a powerful technique for characterizing the central metal atoms with ultrahigh sensitivity, Mössbauer spectroscopy has been employed to prove the existence of Fe-N x sites in the Fe-N-C based catalysts. Generally, the Mössbauer spectroscopy for isolated Fe atoms can be deconvoluted into the doublets D1, D2 and D3 ascribed to low-, intermediate- and high-spin Fe(II) in FeII-N x sites, as well as the doublets D4 and D5 ascribed to low- and intermediate-spin Fe(III) in FeIII-N x sites, while some of the above components might be absent according to the states of Fe atoms in DACs [124,125]. In the 57Fe Mössbauer spectra for (Fe,Co)/N-C [65], the fitted results show the doublets D1, D2 and D3, which are assigned to FeII-N4 configurations with Fe(II) in low-, intermediate- and high-spin state. In addition, a minor amount of singlet Fe component also emerges in the spectra, probably related to the presence of Fe−Co bonds (Fig. 11(a) ). In another example of Fe-Cu DAC [105], the 57Fe Mössbauer spectra for both NCAG/Fe-Cu and NCAG/Fe-Fe present D1 and D2 doublets with different quadrupole splitting (QS) values. In this case, D1 with a lower mean QS value is attributed to FeN4 in high spins, and D2 with a higher one is attributed to FeN4 in low and intermediate spins. The proportion of D2 increases from 47.7% for NCAG/Fe-Fe to 59.8% for NCAG/Fe-Cu, implying that the spin state of Fe atoms decreases after Cu doping (Figs. 11(b) and (c)). These experimental proofs are essential to uncover the synergistic effect of hetero metal atoms and investigate the structure-activity relationships of dual-atom sites. 4.2 In-situ/operando characterization during ORR Although above characterizations are able to give some key information about the geometric structure of dual-atom sites and valence states of central metal atoms, the true active sites and their working mechanisms may not be reflected as the electrode potential has not been take into account. In-situ/operando approaches can track the state evolutions of oxygen intermediates and dual-atom sites during ORR, which is important for understanding the structure-activity relationships of DACs. In-situ/operando spectroscopic techniques involving XAS and Raman spectroscopy have been employed to observe the ORR process on active sites in real-time. 4.2.1 In-situ/operando XAS In-situ/operando XAS technique can indicate the changes of bond length and valence states of central metal atoms, which indirectly demonstrate the interaction between active sites and oxygen species during ORR. According to the operando XANES spectra, Zhang et al. [68] found that the fitted oxidation state of Fe species in Fe2N6 sites is +2.79 at open circuit, which is between +2 and +3, indicating the structure of O2-Fe3+-Fe2+ (Fig. 12(a) ). As applied potential decreasing, the adsorption edge shifted to lower energy, along with broadening of the white line peak, which demonstrates the proceeding of ORR. Furthermore, the local coordination environment changes of Fe sites during ORR process were also investigated by Fe K-edge EXAFS oscillations. In Fig. 12(b), two distinct peaks at 1.5 and 2.2 Å were ascribed to the Fe-N/O and Fe-Fe shell, respectively. The diminishing intensity of Fe-N/O shell at low applied potential suggested the desorption of oxygen species from Fe sites. Notably, a shrinkage of Fe−Fe bond occurred at 1.0 V compared with that at open circuit, which implied a bridge adsorption of oxygen intermediates (such as OOH*), thereby boosting the cleavage of O–O bonds. These phenomena exhibit the synergistic effect of adjacent Fe atoms and advantages of dual-atom sites for ORR. Our previous work [67] observed a relieved site-blocking effect of Fe-Co dual-atom sites (FeCoN x /C) compared with isolated Fe sites (FeN x /C) by Fe K-edge in-situ XANES spectra. As the potential increased from 0.4 to 1.0 V, Fe K-edge for both FeCoN x /C and FeN x /C shifted to higher energy, indicating that the axial –O/OH to Fe sites raised the average valence of Fe (Figs. 12(c) and (d)). Specially, on the first derivative of normalized XANES spectra, a retarded oxidation of Fe occurred on FeCoN x /C, while its intensity of Fe3+ characteristic peak (7127.8 eV) raised slower than that of FeN x /C as potential increased (Figs. 12(e) and (f)). The suppressed oxidation of Fe means that more Fe sites may be accessible on FeCoN x /C at the running potentials, improving its catalytic activity for ORR. The in-situ/operando XAS techniques have provided robust support for understanding the catalytic mechanisms of DACs. 4.2.2 In-situ Raman spectroscopy By collecting real-time information of molecules with Raman active vibrational modes, in-situ Raman spectrum is an effective tool for detecting reaction intermediates, monitoring their dynamic changes, and further elucidating the ORR mechanisms. Jiang et al. [92] conducted in-situ Raman measurements to tracking the oxygen intermediates on Fe-Co dual-atom sites during ORR process in both acidic and alkaline media. With the applied potential negatively shifting, the intensities of Raman peaks ascribed to FeOOH (396 cm−1) and CoOOH (605 cm−1) slightly increased as those ascribed to Fe(OH)2 (441 cm−1) and Co(OH)2 (500 cm−1) decreased, indicating the transformation of FeOOH/CoOOH to Fe(OH)2/Co(OH)2 in catalytic reaction (Figs. 13(a) and (b) ). Based on above results, Fe and Co atoms in this Fe-Co DAC simultaneously serve as the active sites for ORR. In another research proposed by Ma et al. [76], in-situ Raman spectra were employed to demonstrate the OER process on Fe-Ni dual atom sites. As the applied potential approaches 1.7 V, a new band at 557 cm−1 assigned to characteristic peak of FeOOH appears. (Fig. 13(c)). Accordingly, the Fe sites could be responsible for OER, while the Ni sites may act as mediators to optimize the properties of adjacent Fe sites. In-situ Raman spectroscopy can provide important auxiliary evidence for identifying the actual active centers of dual-atom sites in catalytic reactions. 5 Theoretical exploration of Fe-M-N-C based DACs As complementary information for characterization techniques and experimental analysis, theoretical modeling plays a vital role to explore the electronic structures and reaction mechanisms of ORR catalysts [126]. Symmetric active sites endow DACs with unique adsorption behaviors and superior catalytic activity, but also make it more difficult to design optimal atomic configuration from multiple probable combination of metal species and precisely synthesize atomically dispersed metal dimers. Therefore, theoretical modeling approaches have become one of the most effective tools to guide the design of dual-atom sites and elucidate the specific catalytic mechanism. The existing synthetic methods, characterization techniques and mechanism explanation of DACs are mostly based on the earlier studies on SACs. The employment of theoretical modeling may take our understanding of DACs to a new level. In this section, we briefly introduce four theoretical modeling approaches and their applications on exploration of DACs, including density functional (DFT) calculations, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, microkinetic modeling and machine learning (ML) (Fig. 14 ). 5.1 DFT calculations DFT calculations usually provide accurate information in electronic, magnetic and optical properties of catalysts, which are well-consistent with the experimental results, thereby have been widely used to investigate the mechanism of heterogeneous catalysis [127,128]. Using simplified models with intermediate molecules adsorbed on catalyst surface comprised of a few atomic layers, a typical application of DFT calculations is to obtain the Gibbs free energy change and overpotential values, which can be used to predict the possible pathways and catalytic activity for a specific catalytic reaction [126]. The computational hydrogen electrode scheme in DFT calculations can incorporate the impact of the applied electric potential and bulk pH on the reaction thermodynamics. [16]. The Gibbs free energy diagram can be drawn with the calculated Gibbs free energy change, ΔG, in which a higher ΔG means the corresponding reaction step is harder to proceed thermodynamically. The step with the highest ΔG is defined as the potential-limiting step (PLS), which can be used to calculate the theoretical overpotential value of a catalytic reaction [16,129,130]. Selecting appropriate performance descriptor is a crucial factor to conveniently indicate the catalytic activity and guide the design of catalysts. Given the linear scaling relationships between adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates during ORR, the adsorption free energy of catalysts for key intermediates, such as OH*, is considered to be a reliable descriptor, which is derived from the DFT calculations [127,128]. This adsorption energy should be neither too strong nor too weak to get an optimal activity [20]. In addition, the DFT-calculated d-band center [131], position of lowest occupied state [132] and integrated COHP [133] are also utilized as descriptors, building a connection between electronic structures and catalytic activities [134]. According to these descriptors, one can reasonably estimate the modulation effect of second metal atoms to the electronic properties of Fe atoms in a Fe-M-N-C based DAC, thereby forecasting the performance of catalysts or validating the experimental results. However, owing to the complexity of dual-atom configuration, other cogent descriptors holistically reflecting interaction between different metal atoms and respective properties of each metal atoms may be attractive for the future research. Moreover, DFT calculations can provide referable values about the stability of specific models, which is essential for the construction of dual-atom sites in DACs. The formation energy, E f, of active sites can be achieved from the energy difference between energy of active sites and total energy of substrate and metal atoms in metal bulk. A more negative E f means thermodynamically stable configuration of this dual-atom sites. Similarly, dissolution potential, U diss, considering electron transfer, is employed to represent the electrochemically stability [135,136]. Still, these calculations based on simplified models have neglected some inherent issues of catalysts, such as carbon oxidation, Fenton reaction in Fe-N-C catalysts. 5.2 AIMD simulations AIMD simulations enable dynamics observations of active sites in different environments. As a supplement of DFT calculations, AIMD simulation can further prove the stability of dual-atom sites under the effect of external fields. Ouyang et al. perform the structure evolution of different configurations of dual-atom sites at high temperature and in acidic solution, respectively, by AIMD simulations. The structures of dual-atom sites always maintain unaltered, showing strong tolerance to thermal decomposition and acidic dissolution. With the comprehensive consideration of operating environment, AIMD simulations is a promising technique to provide in-situ insight to the degradation of Fe-M-N-C based catalysts. Furthermore, AIMD approaches are also used to simulate the process of catalytic reaction at atomic level, which may be helpful to deepen the understanding of the catalytic mechanism of DACs [137]. 5.3 Microkinetic modeling Microkinetic modeling approaches can be utilized to determine of rate constants and concentration effects in heterogeneous catalysis, which are also obtained by experimental measurements, including turnover frequency (TOF) and selectivity toward the desired products [138,139]. In a typical microkinetic simulation, a reaction network is constructed with all the intermediate steps during the whole reaction, and accordingly the time-dependent concentration variation of intermediate species is achieved by solving associated equations with initial concentration. By virtue of rapidity and low-cost, microkinetic modeling can simplify the analysis of catalytic process and predict the experimental result to some extent, especially for the research on DACs with complicated preparation. 5.4 Machine learning Machine learning is a newly emerging method to predict the properties of various materials and facilitate the design of superior catalysts, which has been employed on the studies about SACs, alloys, etc. [140–142] The traditional high-throughput screening based on quantum methods provides an opportunity to screen potential catalysts with desirable geometric and electronic properties among a mass of candidates, but the huge computational cost still impedes its further development. Machine learning approaches can extract patterns and correlations from numerous experimental and calculational data, and accordingly identify the key parameters, descriptors, connecting the atomic configuration and catalytic performance. A general ML process for catalysts exploration includes database collecting, descriptors identification, ML algorithms selection and model validation. Some common algorithms for catalysts exploration contain neural networks (NN), Gaussian processes regression (GPR), decision trees, random forests regression (RFR), support vector machines (SVM) and so on, which should be further trained with database and then validated by independent cases [140,141]. Zhu et al. [143] employed the DFT calculations and gradient boosted regression (GBR) ML algorithm to investigate the ORR catalytic activity of the graphene-based DACs, TM1/TM2-N6-C. It was found that some fundamental factors, such as electron affinity, electronegativity, and radii of the embedded metal atoms, governed the ORR activity of these DACs. Using GBR algorithm trained by these factors, a precise prediction of adsorption energy, ΔG OH* (descriptor of ORR activity), was realized, and well consistent with the results of DFT calculations. This work proposes a promising way to accelerate the search for highly effective DACs. The complexity of dual-atom sites on DACs raises the difficulty of experimental analysis but generates a larger database compared with SACs, and thus the combination of DFT calculation and machine learning may furnish the development of DACs with a short cut [144,145]. 6 Marriage-type Fe-M-N-C-based DACs The marriage-type DACs are defined as two kinds of separated single-atom sites, which are randomly distributed all over the support matrix. The distances between Fe and the other atoms are not strictly defined. Although there is no direct evidence of electronic interaction between two single-atom sites, these Fe-M-N-C based DACs still exhibit optimized catalytic performance due to the synergistic effects of various active sites. In this section, the recent advances in marriage-type Fe-M-N-C based DACs will be summarized. The overall ORR activity of Fe-N-C materials is fettered by the abundance and intrinsic properties of Fe-N x sites [146–148] One of the conspicuous advantages of DACs is introducing new active sites with different metal centers, M-N x sites, by feeding metal precursor during synthesis [36]. Therefore, some new metal atoms have been brough in Fe-N-C catalysts as extra active sites, and synergistically catalyze ORR process with Fe single-atoms. Fang et al. [149] reported a pyrolyzed FeCo-N-doped porous carbon (FeCo2-NPC-900), which derived from metalloporphyrinic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), PCN-224-FeCo. TEM images and corresponding mappings proved that the uniform distribution of metal elements without obvious agglomeration (Fig. 15(a) ). The optimized catalysts exhibited superior catalytic activity with a half-wave potential of 0.87 and 0.74 V (versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) in alkaline and acidic solutions, respectively. (Figs. 15(b) and (c)). Specifically, Co species (Co-N x ) contributes to the high graphitization and conductivity of carbon network, and work as complemental active sites for ORR with Fe-N x . This work introduced two isolated metal centers into ORR catalysts, but the function of dual-atom sites was not deeply explored. It is of significance to carry on future studies due to the introduction of a new variable. Similarly, inspired by the biological heme-copper oxidases in enzymatic activity, Gong et al. [150] designed a MOFs derived Fe-Mn-N-C DAC (Fe,Mn-N/C) with dispersed Fe-N4 sites and Mn-N4 active sites in porous carbon. The prepared catalyst displays remarkable alkaline ORR performance with a half-wave potential of 0.904 V, superior to that of commercial Pt/C and Fe-N/C. Wang et al. [76] also synthesized a Fe-Mn-N-C catalyst (Mn-Fe-N/S@mC) comprising Fe-N4 sites and a trace number of Mn-N2S2 sites, based on the pyrolysis and etching of self-assembled Mn0.43Fe2.57O4 supracrystals. TEM images show brighter spots corresponding to Fe or Mn atoms are uniformly dispersed throughout the carbon framework (Fig. 15(d)). DFT calculation based on the given model indicates the synergistic effect of Fe-N4 and traced Mn-N2S2 endows the obtained catalyst with enhanced ORR activity by reducing the whole energy barrier of four-electron pathway (Figs. 15(e) and (f)). In this work, the obtained computational results support the experimental data, but the accuracy of the model and calculation should be reconsidered due to the lack of characterization of the dual-atom sites. In the early exploration of Fe-M-N-C based DACs, the simple combination of two kinds of metal atoms results in improved catalytic activity. However, due to the lack of detailed discussion on the geometry and electronic structure of the active site (including characterizations and theoretical calculations), it is not conducive to the further research on catalytic mechanism and establish a reliable structure-activity relationship of DACs. In addition, the M-N x sites can possibly regulate some complex reactions and improve the integrated performance during catalytic process. For example, the introduced M atoms can serve as active sites for oxygen evolution reaction, while Fe atoms are responsible for ORR, realizing bifunctional catalysts for broader applications such as metal-air batteries [101,102]. In another case, the second metal atoms improve the elimination of detrimental reactive oxygen species (ROS), products from Fenton reaction involving Fe sites and H2O2, thereby mitigating the degradation problem in Fe-N-C based catalysts. We [151] recently reported an atomically-dispersed Fe-Ce DAC (Fe,Ce-N-C) with excellent durability in acidic medium, superior to that of Fe-N-C. Single-atom FeN x primarily accounts for the ORR activity. On the basis of the spectral and mass spectrometry analysis, CeN x presents unique function in scavenging the ROS generated on FeN x sites (Figs. 15(g) and (h)), as well as prompting the 4e− ORR process by accelerating the spontaneous decomposition of H2O2 (Fig. 15(i)). Consequently, the resultant catalysts are protected from the corrosive Fenton reaction, exhibiting only 22 mV decay in half-wave potential after 30000 cycles in an accelerated degradation test, and 10% loss of its peak power density after the 30000-voltage cycling accelerated stress test in proton-exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC). It is expected to improve the stability of the catalysts through the reasonable design of DACs and realize their practical applications in PEMFC. By introducing metal atoms with unique functions into DACs, one can readily adjust the overall performance of catalysts and feasibly expand their working cases. Table 1 summarizes some marriage-type Fe-M-N-C based DACs with specific functions of the second metal atoms. 7 Conjunct-type Fe-M-N-C-based DACs The isolated metal atoms in an active site of conjunct-type Fe-M-N-C based DACs are recognized to be spatially adjacent to each other, and thus the synergistic effect of two metal atoms is able to change the adsorption configuration of oxygen intermediates and modulate the electronic structure of the dual-atom sites, endowing them distinct catalytic performance. Based on the metal species in the active sites, which are the same or different, Conjunct-type Fe-M-N-C-based DACs can be classified as homonuclear and heteronuclear. 7.1 Homonuclear DACs Homonuclear Fe2-N-C based DACs consist of two identical Fe atom centers and coordinated N atoms supported on carbon matrix [152], where two adjacent Fe atoms can both act as adsorption sites for reactants and intermediates during ORR process. The activation of adsorbed O2 is an important step during the ORR process, especially for a favorable four-electron pathway with cleavage of O–O bond. The most notable feature of homonuclear DACs is that Fe-Fe dual-atom sites are able to potentially provide multiple adsorption configurations of oxygen species, and accelerate the oxygen reduction process by elongating and wakening O–O bond. Ye et al. [66] investigated how the number of central Fe atoms in adsorption sites influence the acidic ORR process, with precisely controlled single-atom Fe-N4, dual-atom Fe2-N6 and triple-atom Fe3-N4 sites achieved by the pyrolysis of different metal precursor (Figs. 16(a)–(c) ). It is proved by low-temperature Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (LT-FTIR) that Fe1-N-C mainly shows superoxo-like adsorption (end-on model) of O2, while Fe2-N-C and Fe3-N-C favor peroxo-like adsorption (bridge model) of O2 as the interatomic distances between Fe atoms are shortened compared with single-atom sites (Fig. 16(d)). The perpoxo-like adsorption enhances the stretch of O–O bonds and activate O2 molecules, thus benefiting to the ORR process (Figs. 16(e)–(j)). Compared with Fe3-N-C, Fe2-N-C possesses similar adsorption configuration, but a stronger bonding hybridization with O2 molecules, facilitating the electron transfer to activate O2. In addition, Fe1 and Fe2 promote graphitization of carbon and formation of pyridinic N species during pyrolysis process, together with the adsorption configuration of O2, making Fe2-N-C the most promising ORR catalyst among three candidates. As a result, Fe2-N-C displays excellent ORR activity in acidic media with a half-wave potential of 0.78 V, as well as superior stability with a potential shift only 20 mV after 20000 cycles (Figs. 16(h) and (i)). This work enables precise regulation of muti-atom sites through precursor preselection, and makes a pioneering conclusion of the effect of the number of Fe atoms in atomic clusters on ORR activity. Nonetheless, the catalytic activity of Fe2-N-C is still unsatisfactory. Thereafter, Zhang et al. [68] proposed a planar-like Fe2N6 site, obtained by combining individual FeN4 sites during thermal migration on graphitized carbon matrix. From operando EXAFS spectra, an obvious contraction of Fe–Fe bond occurs from open circuit to 1.0 V (Fig. 16(j)). In addition, the redox transition from initial O2-Fe3+-Fe2+to final Fe2+-Fe2+ is also observed during ORR on Fe2N6 sites. Accordingly, planer-like Fe2N6 structure is considered to adsorb O2 on one side, and subsequently present a peroxo-like adsorption of oxygen intermediate OOH*, where two adjacent Fe atoms each bind an O atom, and thus driving the breaking of O–O bond and accelerating four-electron pathway of ORR (Fig. 16(k)). Benefiting from the favoring adsorption configuration and accelerated ORR kinetics, planer-like Fe2N6 structure exhibits optimized catalytic activity (half-potential of 0.84 V, Fig. 16(l)) and stability, and its further application in PEMFCs obtains a peak power density of 845 mW cm−2, much higher than that of single-atom Fe-N4 sites. This activation of oxygen by changing the adsorption configuration is enlightening for the research of DACs, but some reports have shown that the activity of homonuclear Fe2-N-C catalysts is limited by their even higher adsorption energy than Fe-N-C [78,105]. Therefore, how to optimize the adsorption energy of Fe2-N-C catalysts and further improve their catalytic performance may need to be considered in future studies. Although atomically dispersed Fe-N-C catalysts are deemed to be the most hopeful choices for ORR among a series of SACs, their intrinsic activity still remains unsatisfactory compared to commercial Pt/C, ascribable to the too-strong Fe–O bond between Fe-N4 sites and oxygen species [19,20,31]. The modification of electron withdrawing ligands on central metal atoms or neighboring carbon have been proved to be effectual in weakening the oxygen adsorption energy [10,31,67,153]. Hence, we [154] have developed axial O groups bonded dual-atom Fe sites on carbon support (Fe(Zn)-N-C), forming Fe–O–Fe bridge bond, attained by carbon precursor (resorcinol-formaldehyde resin) chelating Fe with six oxygen functional groups. Among proposed various models, a bilayer HO-FeN4CLayer-O-FeN4CLayer-OH structure is in agreement with experimental results, and thermodynamically stable owing to the bridge bonded O (Fig. 17(a) ). Fig.17 (b) depicts the proposed ORR mechanism on 2L-Up sites, where the rate determining step of ORR, the last protonation process of OH* to H2O, is markedly facilitated (Fig. 17(c)). Bader charge analysis reveals that Fe–O–Fe bond induces the charge transfer from d orbital of Fe to O, weakening the adsorption of oxygen on Fe sites (Fig. 17(d)). Consequently, the prepared catalysts perform impressive ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.83 V and enhanced durability with a potential shift of only 14 mV after 10000 cycles in acidic electrolyte (Figs. 17(e) and (f)). This work provides a new perspective for deftly modulating the electronic structure of dual-atom sites and pursuing highly effective catalysts for ORR. As a direct derivative of Fe-N-C catalysts, the major feature distinguishing homonuclear Fe2-N-C based DACs is two adjacent Fe atoms without metal agglomerations. Therefore, the relative position of Fe atoms should be precisely and strictly controlled during the synthesis process. In above works, researchers have achieved dual-atom Fe sites through precursor preselection and thermal mitigation. Specifically, the former needs to preselect metal precursors containing dual-atomic structure and maintain its configuration after pyrolysis [66], and the latter usually randomly couples two individual Fe atoms by their mitigation on substrate under appropriate pyrolysis [68]. Both of them have to be carefully constricted over temperature and time of pyrolysis to inhibit excessive aggregation of Fe atoms. To stabilize the Fe dimers, some supplementary methods have been applied in the preparation. For example, an interfacial cladding strategy with polydopamine was employed to immobilize the metal dimer precursor on the surface of MOF during pyrolysis [155]. The steric effect of covering polydopamine can fix the Fe dimers after harsh annealing, but it may also hinder the exposure of active sites for ORR to interact with oxygen species. Still and all, considering the ratio of single atoms and dimers, the cost of high temperature pyrolysis, and the overall activity as well as stability of catalysts, the controlled preparation of such kindred DACs still needs further exploration to realize steady properties of catalysts and a large-scale production. Some homonuclear Fe2-N-C catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . 7.2 Heteronuclear DACs Heteronuclear Fe-M-N-C based DACs feature dual-atom sites composed of Fe and another metal atom. Despite homonuclear Fe-M-N-C based DACs have been proved to accelerate the kinetics of ORR, heteronuclear DACs are more promising in boosting the ORR performance to a new stage due to the synergistic effect between different metal elements. Several properties of heteronuclear DACs are considered to raise their overall performance with rational design, which are summarized as below. 7.2.1 Internuclear distance between two metal atoms For heteronuclear DACs, the distance and geometric configuration between two metal atoms are crucial factors for the catalysts. When two metal atoms are spatially close enough, the metal-metal bond between them can generate a significant effect on the electronic structure of each other. Besides, the electronic regulation can still work through metal-bridge between metal atoms, even in a relatively long range [111,156,157]. Based on the result of DFT calculations, Tamtaji et al. [94] pointed out that the non-bonding interaction of counterpart metals is able to tune the electronic properties and catalytic activity of Fe sites in DAC systems with interatomic distance below 15 Å. The theoretical ORR overpotential increases with the internuclear distance (Fig. 18(a) ). Specifically, both the configurations of FeNiN6 (Fe–Ni distance of 2.58 Å) and FeNiN8 (Fe–Ni distance of 7.58 Å) endow Fe sites with high spin density as well as high Bader charge transfer by delivering charge through intervening ligands, favoring the OH* desorption to release H2O and improving the ORR process (Figs. 18(b)–(d)). The subsequent experiments with FeCoN8-DAC and FeNiN8-DAC also verify their conclusion of theoretical analysis. Likewise, Brea et al. [158] constructed 31 possible structural configurations of dual-atom sites by using the hexagonal lattice of graphene, including three Fe-M-N6, three Fe-M-N7 and 25 Fe-M-N8. According to the computational predictions, in the case of Fe-Cu DACs, most of them are thermodynamic stable with more negative formation energies than Fe or Cu SACs, and preferable after pyrolysis. It is noteworthy that the calculations reveal the theoretical ORR activity of Fe-Cu DACs is in a linear relationship with the magnetic moment on Fe, which are manipulated by the adjacent metal atoms. The neighboring effect gets stronger as the internuclear distance reduces, and these distances of top five configurations in ORR activity are all less than 4.5 Å (Fig. 18(e)). Therefore, decreasing the distance between metal atoms might be a potential strategy to design DACs with high ORR activity. Similar argument has also been stated in another study about Fe-Cu DACs [159]. Interestingly, Hu et al. [160] stated that the relationship between internuclear distance and catalytic activity of Fe-Co DACs is not monotonically increasing. They systematically investigated the catalytic performance of Fe-Co-N-C catalysts with 25 different models by DFT calculations, including FeCoN6, FeCoN7 and FeCoN8. It was shown that the atomic configurations of FeCoN7 and FeCoN8 possesses a higher activity for both ORR and OER compared with FeCoN6. In this case, the top site of Co atoms is considered to be the major active sites, whose d-band centers can be regulated by the neighboring Fe atoms and fairly related to the adsorption strength with the reaction intermediates. For FeCoN6 with shorter internuclear distance, the excessive adsorption strength hinders the progress of catalytic reactions with a much higher energy barrier (Figs. 18(f)–(i)). Therefore, when designing the dual-atom sites, much attention should be paid to the relationship among internuclear distance, electronic structure, and catalytic activity of DACs. 7.2.2 Adsorption configuration of oxygen species As two metal atoms in DACs are relatively close, the first thing to be noticed is the regulation of adsorption configurations of oxygen species by dual-atom sites. Two metal atoms can simultaneously serve as adsorption sites for O2, elongating and weakening the O–O bond, thus promoting the ORR process. Wang et al. [65] designed a N-doped porous carbon catalyst embedded with Fe-Co dual sites, (Fe,Co)/N-C, by a host-guest strategy. The spectral characterizations reveal that Fe-Co dual metal sites exist in a configuration of the porphyrin-like structure, FeCoN6, with metal-metal bond between Fe and Co atoms (Fig. 19(a) ). DTF calculation results manifest that Fe-Co dual sites bind strongly with O2 molecules, activating O–O bond from 1.23 to1.40 Å and facilitating the dissociation of O2 and OOH into O and OH. As a result, the rate-determining step of ORR on (Fe,Co)/N-C, the hydrogeneration of adsorbed OH, exhibits a much lower energy barriers of 0.26 eV than that on Fe/N-C (0.65 eV) and Pt-based catalysts (~0.80 eV), the cleavage of O–O bond (Fig. 19(c)). The achieved catalyst shows superior ORR activity in acidic electrolyte with half-wave potential of 0.863 V (Fig. 19(b)). This work has innovatively explained the advantages of dual-atom sites for electrocatalysis in a view of adsorption configuration, and stimulated the subsequent intensive research on DACs. After that, the same group [71] also reported Fe-Co dual-atom sites embedded in N-doped carbon nanotubes and broadened its application in zinc-air battery. The superior ORR activity of the catalyst originates the activation of O2 by weakening O–O bonds. A similar O2 activation effect has also been observed in a Fe-Cu system. Sun et al. [78] prepared a Fe-Cu DACs (FeCu-N-HC) to accelerate the ORR process. The theoretical calculations demonstrate that after O2 molecules are adsorbed on the FeCuN6 sites with Fe–Cu bond, O–O bond will be elongated from the original value of 1.21 to 1.39 Å, benefiting its subsequent dissociation (Fig. 19(d)). Among five models, owing to the optimal OO* formation energy, FeCuN6 performs the highest thermodynamic limiting potential during downhill steps of ORR process, indicating its outstanding catalytic activity in theory (Figs. 19(e) and (f)). Cui et al. [83] constructed Fe-Mn dual-atom sites on 2D ultrathin N-doped carbon nanosheets (FeMn-DSAC). In the proposed model, both Fe and Mn atoms are coordinated with four nitrogen atoms, with no direct metal–metal bond detected. DFT relaxations manifest that the small internuclear distance between Fe and Mn atoms enables FeMnN6 clusters to adsorb intermediates OOH* in a “lying down“ configuration, in which one O atom is on the top of Fe atom and the other O atom is on the top of Mn atom. This unique adsorption configuration favors the dissociation of OOH* into O* and OH* on the top of two metal sites and hence accelerate the ORR process (Fig. 19(g)). However, the acidic performance of some above DAC systems has not been verified. In addition, despite favorable adsorption configuration occurring in various DAC systems, how the metal species in dual-atom sites influence the adsorption behavior and catalytic performance has not been discussed in detail. With two metal centers close to each other, Fe-M-N-C based DACs may enable reaction pathway that are inaccessible to SACs, conducting a different catalytic mechanism. The four-electron pathway of ORR process is favorable for higher energy density. The associative pathway is mostly reported in the studies of DACs, while the high energy barrier of O–O bond cracking for O2* can be avoided through hydrogenation to OOH* [9,161,162]. Some Fe-M-N-C based DACs in specific configurations are considered to accelerate the four-electron pathway by manipulating the position or species of oxygen intermediates. Chen et al. [163] proposed a dual-site cascade mechanism of ORR based on dual metal sites dispersed on N-doped carbon matrix (Fe/Mn-N x -C). Fe-Mn dual-atom sites exist in the configuration of FeMnN6 with Fe-Mn coordination of 2.41 Å (Fig. 20(a) ), where both Fe and Mn potentially work as active centers during ORR. According to the DFT calculations, the first three steps of four-electron pathway are more likely to occur on the Fe sites to generate OOH* and O* intermediates owing to the lower energy barrier, while the last step corresponding to the electroreduction of OH* is accomplished on the Mn sites due to the preferred adsorption of OH* (Figs. 20(b) and (c)). The transfer of OH* intermediates from Fe sites to adjacent Mn sites follows a cascade adsorption mechanism, which overcomes the conundrum of low adsorption energy of OH* on Fe-N x sites (Fig. 20(d)). Nonetheless, this cascade mechanism should be further validated by more in-situ characterization in molecular level. Recently, Xie et al. [80] reported a direct O–O cleavage (dissociation pathway) and accelerated ORR kinetics on Fe-Zn diatomic pairs supported by carbon matrix (Fe-Zn@SNC). A configuration of FeZnN5S with pre-controlled interatomic distance of approximately 3 Å is obtained by a bi-functional ligand-assisted strategy (Fig. 20(e)). DFT calculations reveal that the direct O–O bond cleavage mechanism only occurs with the limited interatomic distance in range of 2.88 to 3.26 Å (Figs. 20(f) and (g)). In a model of Fe-Zn pairs in 3.16 Å, Fe and Zn atoms possess the highest and the most balanced electron density, and prefer a bridge adsorption model (Figs. 20(h)–(j)). The equivalent interaction with two oxygen atoms in bridge model enables a larger electron transfer to O2, leading to higher filled states in the oxygen antibonding-orbitals, thereby boosting O–O bond cleavage in adsorbed O2 to skip the sluggish kinetics of O2*→OOH*. As a result, the as-prepared Fe-Zn catalyst exhibits outstanding catalytic activity with a half-wave potential of 0.86 V and enhanced stability in acid electrolyte (Figs. 20(k) and (l)). This work indicates that the geometric configuration of the dual-atom sites, in which the two metal centers should not be too close or too far, determines its electronic structure, thus influencing its adsorption behavior and catalytic performance. In summary, dual-atom sites can potentially regulate the adsorption configuration of oxygen intermediates, thus activating the O–O bonds and even triggering unique mechanism of four-electron pathway to improve ORR process. 7.2.3 Electronic structure of active metal atoms The interaction between metal atoms in a dual-metal stie provides a feasible access to modulate the electronic structure of Fe site and boost its intrinsic activity [36,54,57]. In general, this enhanced activity of Fe centers by electronic structure modulation can be explained following two possible mechanisms, the activation of O–O bonds and the alleviation of Fe–O binding strength. On the one hand, the enriched electrons at Fe sites from neighboring metal atom can be further transferred to the 2p anti-bonding orbitals of adsorbed oxygen atoms, leading to the activation of O–O bonds and acceleration of ORR process. On the other hand, when the d-band center of Fe in the dual-atom sites shifts down, the excessive adsorption strength of Fe atoms to oxygen species is able to be balanced and the sluggish desorption steps during ORR will be improved [92,106–108]. Accordingly, intensive studies have been developed to raise the intrinsic activity of Fe in a dual-atom configuration. The electron transfer from neighboring metal atoms to Fe atoms and further to oxygen atoms is regarded one of the most significant electronic effects to activate adsorbed oxygen. By mimicking the natural Cytochrome oxidase, Du et al. [164] designed a Fe-Cu DAC for ORR, FeCu-DA/NC, containing FeN4 sites and CuN4 sites anchored in three-dimensional porous N-doped carbon. The statistical analysis based on the TEM images shows that the distance between two metal atoms is about 5 Å, indicating no metal-metal bonds formed in the dual metal sites (Fig. 21(a) ). The DFT calculations unveil that the introduction of adjacent Cu atoms raises the electron density around Fe atoms (Fig. 21(b)). Consequently, O2 molecules can be adsorbed by the FeN4CuN4 sites with modest adsorption strength and get more transferred electron with larger orbital overlap, beneficial to the activation and further reduction of O2 (Figs. 21(c) and (d)). Therefore, the FeCu-DAC/NC exhibits the lowest theoretical energy barrier and superior catalytic activity among various counterparts (Figs. 21(e) and (f)). Despite its outstanding activity in alkaline media, the half-wave potential of FeCu-DAC/NC in 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4 solution is below 0.8 V, which is not competitive in recently reported catalysts. Zhu et al. [75] reported a Fe-Ni DAC (Fe/Ni-N x /OC) with Fe-N4 and Ni-N4 sites supported by a micro-sized nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon. DFT calculations reveal that a long-range interaction between adjacent Fe-N4 sites and Ni-N4 sites brings a synergistic effect, whereas the electrons can be transferred from Ni atoms to Fe atoms through the conjugated π bond of graphene, thus increasing the electronic density around Fe sites and increasing the ORR activity. As ORR catalyst, the Fe/Ni-N x /OC conveys an excellent catalytic activity in both alkaline and acidic solutions with half-wave potentials of 0.938 and 0.840 V, respectively, far exceeding the Fe or Ni SACs. Indeed, it cannot fully represent the whole catalytic process to explain the modulation effect of dual-atom sites by just O2 activation with electron transfer. The electronic structure of Fe should be studied in depth considering the adjacent metal atoms. Han et al. [84] managed promoting the ORR activity of FeN4 moiety by the modulation effect of adjacent Pt-N4 moiety. It is theoretically supported that Pt-N4 moiety play a role of a modulator instead of an active center. The Pt-N4 modulators aid the O2 adsorption process on the Fe-N4 sites and stretch O–O bond in a higher degree, enabling an easier breakage of O2 molecule (Fig. 21(g)). On the other hand, adjacent Pt-N4 sites vary the energy levels and spatial contribution of Fe 3d orbitals and regulate the rehybridization of Fe d and O p orbitals with more bonding orbitals, thus enhancing the adsorption of OOH*, O* and OH* on Fe-N4 sites (Figs. 21(h) and (i)). As a result, the potential-limiting step of ORR change from OOH* adsorption to OH* desorption, thereby lowering down the calculated overpotential. Interestingly, this modulation effect of Pt-N4 moiety is negligible or even negative in the systems of Co-N4/Pt-N4 and Mn-N4/Pt-N4, indicating the emphasis of reasonable selection of metal species for dual-atom sites. Concretely, the over-strong Fe–O binding impedes the desorption of OH* to H2O or OH−, making it the rate-determining step of ORR process on Fe-N4 sites, reported by many previous studies [24,165,166]. The d-band center of Fe sites can be regulated by the second metal atoms to lower the adsorption strength of OH*. Wang et al. [167] fabricated a ternary-atom catalysts, Co2/Fe-N@CHC, which consists of dual-atom Co2-N6 sites and single-atom Fe-N4 sites dispersed on highly graphitized carbon matrix (Fig. 22(a) ). According to the DFT calculations, Co2-N6 sites have no significant contribution to the overall activity due to their over-strong adsorption of oxygen intermediates. Nevertheless, the adjacent Co2-N6 sites induce a distinct shift of Fe-d orbitals towards lower energy. The much negative value of corresponding Fe d-band center means more filled antibonding orbitals, weakening the interaction between the active Fe sites and the adsorbed OH* (Fig. 22(b)). The energy barrier of rate-determining step (OH* + e− → OH−) is greatly reduced, enhancing the catalytic activity for ORR (Fig. 22(c)). Similarly, Yang et al. [168] prepared a Fe-Ce DAC, in which 4f cruise electrons of Ce atoms reduce the d-band center of the Fe atoms. As a result, the addition of Ce wakens the adsorption strength between Fe active sites and oxygen intermediates, rendering high ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.81 V in acidic media. The relationship between electronic structure and catalytic performance can be established by reasonable descriptors. For example, the magnetic moment of active Fe atom is attributed to the partially filled d orbitals, and have been regarded as a descriptor for catalytic activity of some SACs [131,169]. He et al. [105] unraveled a nearly linear correlation between the Fe magnetic moment and the energy barriers of key reaction steps through DFT calculations. The combination of Cu-N4 and Fe-N4 sites generates four configurations of dual-atom sites with different metal elements and local environments (Fig. 22(d)). A similar quasi-linear relationship is shown as the Fe magnetic moment increase with the desorption energy of OH* (ΔG OH*) (Fig. 22(e)). Among them, Cu1/Fe1-2 with Fe-N4 at the nanopore and neighboring Cu-N4 enables a more significant diminishment of both magnetic moment and ΔG OH*. A more positive limiting potential on Cu1/Fe1-2 indicates that it is thermodynamically favorable for ORR electrocatalysis (Fig. 22(f)). Specifically, the density of states (DOS) of metal site 3d electrons suggest the higher electron density near Fermi level of Fe under the modulation of neighboring Cu atoms (Fig. 22(g)). And a decrease of Fe magnetic moment in Fe-N4 occurs due to the increased electron density of the specific dz 2 orbital (spin down) (Fig. 22(h)). Guided by the theoretical analysis, a Fe-Cu DAC (NCAG/Fe-Cu) is prepared and possesses a remarkable half-wave potential of 0.94 and 0.84 V in alkaline and neutral solutions, respectively. The effect of electronic structure modulation of active sites has been analyzed from different views to improve the catalytic activity, including weakening O–O bonds and optimizing the adsorption energies to oxygen intermediates, and thus the mechanism of dual-atom sites should be fully considered as a DAC was designed. The properties of some heteronuclear Fe-M-N-C based DACs for ORR are summarized in Table 3 . In addition, a general principle for the correlation between activity and electronic structure of dual atom sites should be established with comprehensive discussion in the future research. 8 Challenges and opportunities With combination of metal species, Fe-M-N-C based DACs are endowed with multiple probable active sites, tunable electronic structures, unique adsorption configuration and other favorable properties, thereby supposed to raise the catalytic performance of Fe-based catalysts for ORR to a new level. However, the research on Fe-M-N-C based DACs is still in its infancy. As newly emerging materials, their development faces challenges as well as opportunities. 8.1 Stability issues Among all transition metal-based SACs, Fe-N-C catalysts perform the highest activity in acidic media, which is now approaching that of commercial Pt/C catalyst. However, the stability issues of Fe-N-C catalysts have become major obstacles to their applications in PEMFC, which causes serious performance loss of 40%–80% during the first 100 h of fuel cell testing [39]. The degradation of Fe-N-C catalysts are explained by several probable mechanisms, including protonation of nitrogen groups [44–46], demetallation [44–46] and carbon oxidation [43,50–52]. Moreover, it is widely accepted that Fe ions or Fe-N x sites will catalyze the decomposition of H2O2 by Fenton reaction to generate aggressive ROS, which keeps attacking the supports and aggravates the carbon corrosion [43,53]. A coupled mechanism with demetallation and carbon oxidation are currently recognized to be predominant in the degradation of Fe-N-C catalysts: The carbon oxidation driven by voltage and ROS leads to the collapse of the carbon matrix as well as the disintegration of metal sites, and the released Fe ions catalyze the generation of ROS in turn. A direct strategy to stabilize Fe-N-C catalysts is minimizing the concentration of ROS from Fenton reaction, including eliminating the generated ROS and reducing the reactant, H2O2. Radical scavengers (FRSs), such as CeO2 and MnO2 nanoparticles, have been reported to scavenge ROS and improve the stability of PEMFC [170]. In a DAC system, it is feasible to bring extra active sites conducting a ROS eliminating reaction. We [103] have proved the isolated Ce atoms endow the Fe-Ce-N-C catalysts with excellent durability in acidic medium, in which CeN x presents unique function in scavenging the ROS generated on neighboring FeN x sites, and catalyzing the spontaneous decomposition of H2O2. On the other hand, removing H2O2 can inhibit the Fenton reaction in terms of its sources, which may be a new target in designing new DACs. Zhang et al. [70] recently reported a distinctive two-electron pathway to further reduce undesired H2O2 to H2O unlocked by Fe-Cu dual-atom sites.
