FeCu-DAC exhibits much higher current density over a broad potential window of 0.1–0.8 V, implying a facilitated H2O2 reduction (Fig. 23(a) ). DFT calculations show that FeCu-DAC possesses a higher energy barrier for Fenton-like reaction and a lower one for hydrogen peroxide reduction reaction (HPRR) owing to the synergistic effect of Fe-Cu metal pairs (Figs. 23(b) and (c)). The guided elementary steps in the catalytic cycle suppress the Fenton reaction and realize high durability of Fe-Cu-N-C catalysts. The role of atomic configuration of DACs in improving the stability of active sites themselves is also worthy of attention. Li et al. [171] proposed a Fe-Zn based diatomic catalyst, Fe/Zn-NC, in which Zn atoms not only facilitates the catalytic activity for ORR but much notably, enhances the stability of FeN4 sites. Fe/Zn-NC shows the highest free energy required for protonation with hydrogen atoms among counterparts, suggesting its potentially superior stability against protonation process (Figs. 23(d) and (e)). The further DTF calculations reveal that N3 and N4 sites in the configuration of FeZnN6 tend to be bonded with the proton, resulting in the breakage of Zn–N bonds and the stretch of Fe–N bonds (Fig. 23(f)). In such protonation process, FeN4 active centers are protected with maintained electronic structure (but with ZnN4 scarified to ZnN2), which endows Fe-Zn diatomic pairs with robust reaction activity and durability in both acidic and alkaline media (Fig. 23(g)). This work provides a distinct perspective to explain the ameliorated stability of DACs, but whether the protonation of nitrogen groups predominantly accounts for the deactivation of the catalysts is still elusive without compelling evidence [5,172]. The introduction of second metal atoms can regulate the properties of DACs in multiple views, which hold an underlying connection with the stability of catalysts. Jaouen et al. [173] identified durable and nondurable Fe-N4 sites in Fe-N-C catalysts with in-situ 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy. Both high-spin FeN4C12 moiety (S1) and low- or intermediate-spin FeN4C10 moiety (S2) initially contribute to the ORR activity. S1 is not stable and spontaneously converts to ferric oxides, while S2 remains stable with high activity. Therefore, increasing the ratio of relatively low-spin S2 might be a new direction to raise the stability of Fe-N x sites. Inspiringly, the variation in spin state of Fe, including the shift to lower spin, has been observed in some Fe-M-N-C systems [69,94,105,174]. Although the spin state of Fe and stability of dual-atom sites has not yet been linked in these works, it is still worth considering in future studies. Likewise, highly graphitized carbon matrix is another common feature of many Fe-N-C catalysts reported with enhanced stability [41]. Metal atoms in DACs can potentially influence the properties of carbon matrix. Fang et al. [149] pointed out that the existence of Co-N x sites in Fe-Co-N-C catalyst increase the graphitization and conductivity of carbon support. Ye et al. [66] believed that Fe dimers catalyze the graphitization of carbon during pyrolysis, leading to higher graphitization degree and promoted electron transport. It may be accessible to explain the stability of DACs through the modification effect of metal species towards carbon substrate. To sum up, it is possible to deal with the stability issues of Fe-N-C catalysts by rational design of DACs. Although some previously reported Fe-M-N-C based DACs have shown improved durability in operating conditions, the specific mechanism to stabilize the catalysts have been rarely investigated [65,85]. More in-depth studies on the structure-stability relationships are still in urgent need. 8.2 Advanced modification strategies Although DACs have shown distinct advantages compared with SACs, the current strategies of simply combining metal species are still insufficient to regulate the intrinsic activity for highly effective catalysts. The further modification towards the geometric and electronic structures of dual-atom sites is of significance, so that some advanced strategies reported in SAC systems should be reasonably considered. In general, a typical single-atom sites features geometric structure consisting of center metal atoms, coordinated atoms, environmental atoms and guest groups, which all show potential capability to regulate the intrinsic activity of atomically dispersed catalysts (Fig. 24(a) ) [10]. Among them, the center metal atoms directly interact with oxygen intermediates and determine the adsorption behaviors, which are mainly discussed in above examples of DACs. In fact, other components in dual-atom sites are also nonnegligible for the design of Fe-M-N-C based DACs. The coordinated atoms directly bond with the center metal atoms and share strong electronic interactions, making them greatly influence the properties of metal atoms. Wang et al. [175] introduced P as coordinated atoms into Fe-Co dual-atom sites by a precursor-preselected method. This configuration of FeCoN5P1 exhibits the lowest formation energy among FeCoN6 and FeN4, and endows the catalyst with a much better durability in PEMFC. Unfortunately, this involvement of P element does not improve the ORR activity of FeCoN5P1/C compared with that of FeCoN6/C due to its too strong adsorption of OH*. Such a sacrifice on activity of catalysts is usually unacceptable. Before a dual-atom site is designed, a trade-off between activity and stability should be carefully considered. The environmental atoms are doped heteroatom in carbon supports and do not directly coordinate with the metal centers, but their electronic modulation effect on active sites still works through long-range delocalization. Zhou et al. [176] prepared Fe-Co dual-atom sites anchored on the N,P co-doped carbon bubbles, forming a configuration of FeCoN6-P (Fig. 24(b)). In this case, P dopants are located near the N3-Fe-Co-N3 sites without direct bonding, contributing to the charge redistribution of dual-atom sites. Therefore, the local electron engineering on FeCoN6-P enables lower energy barrier of rate-determining step, desorption of OH*, and improve the oxygen catalytic activity (Fig. 24(c)). In fact, the effect of heteroatom doping on the ORR activity of DACs is intricate, as the position, quantity, and environment of the doped atoms count for the properties of active sites comprehensively. Typically, the d orbitals of the center metal atoms perpendicular to the catalyst surface will not be fully occupied, and thus can interact with guest groups such as some small molecules. Electron-withdrawing OH ligands from water dissociation can serve as guest groups to regulate the electronic structure of metal centers and improve the ORR process [177,178], but long-term stability of the OH ligands in electrochemical conditions have not been guaranteed. We [67] previously reported an energy level modified strategy on Fe-Co dual metal sites realized by a spontaneously adsorbed OH ligands (Fig. 24(d)). DFT calculations indicate the FeCoN5 sites exhibit a stronger adsorption of oxygen species than FeN4 and generate a wider potential window to stabilize the OH ligand. OH ligands decrease the electron density at the Fe sites and realize a modest adsorption of oxygen intermediates on FeCoN5-OH sites. Consequently, the rate-determining step of OH* desorption is facilitated, thereby enhancing the ORR activity in acidic media (Figs. 24(e) and (f)). Exogenous single metal atoms can also serve as guest groups and form a special configuration of dual-atom sites. Zeng et al. [179] fabricated a Pt-single-atom-grafted Fe-N-C catalyst with a novel Pt1O2-F1N4 active sites. Owing to the steric and electronic effects of Pt1O2 groups, the catalyst exhibits remarkable stability in acidic media and enhanced activity towards ORR, OER and HER. Analogously, other guest groups reported in Fe-N-C systems, such as chloride and cyanide ions, may potentially serve in DACs, synergistically tune the electronic structure of dual-atom sites [153,180]. Fully considering the microenvironment of metal atoms may further elevate the performance of Fe-M-N-C based DACs to a higher stage. Heterojunction materials consisting of Fe-N-C and embedded metal or metal compound nanoparticles have been gradually reported in recent years. Actually, metal-based nanoparticles are endemic for the widely used pyrolysis synthesis of atomically dispersed catalysts. However, these nanoparticles are initially recognized as unfavorable byproducts due to their catalytic inertness for ORR and low atomic utilization efficiency, thereby removed by acid washing after pyrolysis in a general preparation of SACs. Some recent works have proved metal-based nanoparticles on Fe-N-C catalysts contribute to the ORR process by boosting the activity of neighboring Fe-N x sites. The electronic interaction between isolated Fe and nanoparticles have been emphasized. Jiang et al. [181] reported that the coexistence of Fe/Fe3C and Fe-N4 enables high ORR activity. DFT calculations revealed that additional Fe atoms is able to provide extra electron and increase the overlap between the HOMO of catalysts and the LUMO of O2 molecules, thus enhancing the intrinsic ORR activity of Fe-N4 sites. A similar study [182] about composite of Fe/Fe3C and Fe-N-C proposed Fe3C enhances the oxygen affinity of Fe-N4 sites, while Fe promotes the OH* adsorption on Fe-N4 sites, leading to improved ORR kinetics. Hetero metal Pt also have also been studied in heterojunction system to improve the ORR activity, in which the electronegative Pt atoms in Pt-alloy nanoparticles can induce electron transfer from isolated Fe atoms to Pt atoms, leading to weaker adsorption of OH* on Fe-N4 sites [183]. The unique structure of heterojunction enables electronic modulation of isolated metal atoms by nanoparticles, which is also enlightening for the design of advance Fe-M-N-C based DACs. For example, in a typical Fe-Fe DAC, Fe2-N6 sites, can change the adsorption configuration of O2 and accelerate the cleavage of O–O bond, but the excessive adsorption strength of oxygen intermediates hinders the desorption of OH* indeed, making it rate-determining step of ORR process. The electronic interaction between nanoparticles and dual-atom sites can potentially moderate the Fe–O binding, thus promoting the ORR activity. The exploration of advanced strategies, including microenvironment regulation and heterojunction materials, gives more chances to flexibly modulate the electronic structure of Fe centers and improve the intrinsic catalytic activity of dual-atom sites, but it also undoubtedly complicates the DAC system and increases the difficulty of material characterization and mechanism analysis. It is important to consider the modulation factors comprehensively and construct the corresponding structure-effect relationship in the future research. In addition, the stability and cost of catalysts should also be considered as modulation strategies are applied to design preeminent Fe-M-N-C based DACs. 8.3 DACs library Many works have been carried on Fe-M-N-C based DACs to obtain catalysts with superior performance, but a lack of reliable understanding on how to select the most suitable second metal element and construct the optimum dual-atom sites with rational geometric configuration and electronic structure still hinders the rational design of DACs. Due to the large number of metal combinations and the difficulty to synthesize and characterize DACs, traditional trial-and-error methods are time-consuming and hard to control variables. Therefore, an efficient approach is needed to establish a DACs library with exhaustive information and quickly screen numerous potential candidates, accelerating the exploration of Fe-M-N-C based DACs. The precise synthesis of dual-atom sites is the prerequisite of DAC research. Although multiple approaches have been reported to prepare DACs including bottom-up and top-down strategies, it is of importance to develop a general route to achieve a series of DACs. Recently, Zhang et al. [70] demonstrate a macrocyclic precursor-mediated synthesis of a DAC library. Robson-type macrocyclic ligand enables incorporate two metal centers into an in-plane coordination, which are tunable in a wide spectrum (e.g., Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Pd, Rh, Pt, etc.), and retain the atomic pairs in a high level after pyrolysis. The percentage of metal pairs in as-obtained Fe-Cu DAC is about 70% from the TEM images, which is significant to keep a good consistent between the actual catalysts and the theoretical models. This innovation in synthetic method provides an experimental basis for the establishment of DACs library, which significantly broadens the property landscape of DACs. High-throughput screening based on theoretical calculations is an important supplement to experiments, efficiently picking out potential catalysts with distinct geometric and electronic properties from a mass of candidates. In general, various models of potential DACs are constructed according to the accessible geometric structures. Then, some key information of catalysts is achieved by DFT calculations, such as electronic and catalytic properties. Further, the catalysts can be evaluated by computational results that directly correspond to the activity (energy barrier of rate-determining step) and stability (formation energy and dissolution potential). Eventually, the potential catalysts identified have to be validated by experimental approaches. In high-throughput screening, selecting reasonable descriptors will greatly simplify the calculation process and obtain more reliable predictions of actual catalysts. Jia et al. [108] firstly discovered that N3-coordinated-adjacent dual-metal model on graphene support has stronger synergistic and dynamic effects, and then accordingly investigated the DACs with various metal combinations for O2 activation and CO oxidation. To explore some universal descriptors for catalytic performance, 50 relationships were systemically studied, in which charge transfer, average charge on metals, average d-orbital center on metals, and stretching vibrational frequency of reactants may suggest the binding ability/stability of O2. It was shown that Fe-containing DACs, especially Fe-Ni combination, generally more active than others owing to their preferential co-adsorption of CO and O2. The cooperation of experimental and computational approaches helps to build a sound DACs library. However, generally applicable and widely accepted descriptors have not been developed to direct the design of Fe-M-N-C based DACs for ORR. On the other hand, for a more complicated DAC system involving microenvironment or heterojunction structure, it is more challenging to conduct either experiments or calculations. Rapidly developed machine learning and artificial intelligence may be instructive for establishing DACs library covering complex system and understanding the structure-activity relationships at atomic/molecular level. 9 Conclusion and perspective Fe-N-C based SACs have been widely studied because of the relativity high ORR activity of Fe-N x sites and advantageous interaction with carbon matrix. However, their developments are hampered by some drawbacks, including the low metal loading, unsatisfying intrinsic activity, corrosive side reactions and insufficiency for some complex reactions. As an extension of SACs, Fe-M-N-C DACs are considered as promising ORR catalysts to conquer above issues and improve the overall performance with rational design. In this review, we have comprehensively summarized the mechanisms, synthetic approaches, identification techniques and computational methods of DACs in detail. Then, the classification of Fe-M-N-C based DACs are discussed, and accordingly the atomic configurations and corresponding specific properties are elucidated. In addition, some challenges and opportunities of Fe-M-N-C based DACs are emphasized to accelerate their theoretical research and practical applications. The second metal atoms in Fe-M-N-C based DACs can function by synergistic effect and/or modulation effect to promote the overall performance of catalysts. First, the introduced second metal atoms can work as new active sites, providing catalytic activity towards some complex reactions, such as ROS eliminating reaction. Second, two metal atoms with appropriate distance can simultaneously adsorb oxygen, leading to a bridge model of adsorption configuration and acceleration in O–O bond cleavage. Third, the adsorption in dual-atom sites may change the positions or species of oxygen intermediate, guiding to the generation of new reaction pathways for ORR, which are of significant meanings for understanding the principle of oxygen reduction catalysis. On the other hand, the electronic structure of isolated Fe atoms can be modulated by the neighboring metal atoms, thus raising the intrinsic catalytic activity of Fe sites by activating oxygen intermediates or optimizing Fe–O binding strength. Numerous efforts have been devoted to the research of Fe-M-N-C based DACs, which have generated encouraging achievements. However, exploration of DACs is still at an immature stage with massive challenges and opportunities. Herein, some promising directions which may make a landmark should be attached attention in the future. (1) Precise synthesis of dual-atom sites with high loading as well as large-production capacity. Since the geometric structure of dual-atom sites directly determines the performance of DACs, how to precisely control the relative positions of metal atoms during synthetic process has become a critical issue. Single-atom sites inevitably exist on catalysts while metal dimers are recognized as target active sites, which probably impair the practical activity and confuse the structure-activity relationships of DACs, especially conjunct-type DACs. In addition, the current preparation of DACs generally has strict requirements on precursor and pyrolysis condition, so large-scale production of DACs compromising cost and performance is an appealing target considering their practical applications. (2) Credible identification of dual-atom sites. The identification of active sites is a precondition to plumb the structure-activity relationships of DACs. HAADF-STEM only delivers the geometrical information of a nanoscale local areas on catalysts, and the accuracy of available spectrum technology, including XAS and Mössbauer spectroscopy, is greatly dependent on the fitting process. All of them cannot sufficiently present the actual structure of active sites in a global vision, restricting the development of Fe-M-N-C based DACs. (3) Deep understanding of ORR mechanisms on DACs. The reaction mechanism on dual-atoms sites remains obscure due to a shortage of direct evidence from dynamic characterizations. Time-resolved in-situ/operando characterization, such as fast XAS, have potential to detect oxygen intermediates with short lifetime and clarify the reaction pathway. In addition, although computational methods have been widely employed in theoretical exploration, the so-built model usually consists of several layers of atoms and cannot take into account the effect of carbon substrate on catalytic process. Thus, both advanced characterization techniques and computational methods are desired to drive the mechanism study. (4) High stability of DACs in acidic media. Fe-N-C based catalysts face an obstruction in stability. The demetallation and carbon oxidation mechanism coupled by Fenton reaction intensify the degradation of catalysts in acidic media. Specifically, ROS generated from Fenton reaction will attack the carbon matrix as well as active sites, and even corrode components in energy devices, such as the PEMFC membrane [47]. Reasonably selecting the second metal atoms in DACs can improve their stability by eliminating ROS, inhibiting the two-electron pathway, or conducting other possible mechanisms. (5) Optimum configuration of dual-atom sites with peak performance. Among the large number of combinations of metal species, it still remains unclear to construct dual-atom sites with peak performance by selecting optimum second metal atoms and geometric configuration. With the development of synthetic approaches and high-throughput screening assisted by machine learning, a DACs library containing complete database can be establish to accelerate the exploration of optimum configuration of dual-atom sites. (6) Coordination environment regulation of dual-atom sites. In addition to the reasonable design of metal atom centers, regulating the coordination environment of metal atoms on the carbon substrates also significantly affects the catalytic performance of DACs. Multiple elements including coordinated atoms, environmental atoms, guest groups and nanoparticle heterojunctions are expected to further improve the intrinsic activity of dual-atom sites. The electronic modulation effect of environmental factors should be paid more attention. (7) Extension of dual-atom sites to triple- and multi-atom sites. An arresting direction of the DACs is to continue to increase the number of metal centers in the active sites. For example, the metal atoms in triple-atom sites can be present in linear, triangular, or other 3D structures, which improve the flexibility of active sites and expand the potential adsorption configurations of oxygen molecules. Research on these small metal cluster on carbon supports can deepen our understanding of catalytic behavior on metallic nuclei. Still, how to achieve multi-atom sites with stable and specific atomic structures remains formidable. In summary, Fe-M-N-C based DACs possesses natural advantages in reregulating the activity of Fe sites, providing various adsorption sites and breaking the linear relationship between adsorption strength towards oxygen intermediates. Although the issues about precise synthesis, identification techniques, reaction mechanisms and stability optimization remain unsolved, Fe-M-N-C based DACs have achieved considerable attention as a research frontier, giving a new insight for the design of an efficient ORR catalyst. Junjie Ge received her Ph.D. in physical chemistry from Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2010. She worked at University of South Carolina and University of Hawaii as a postdoc fellow for almost 5 years. She joined Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry in 2015 as a professor and then joined University of Science and Technology of China in 2022 as a professor. Her research interests comprehend fuel cells, nanoscience, catalysis, and electrochemistry. She has published 100+ peer-reviewed papers on the highly reputable international journals including Nat. Sci. Rev., Joule, Chem, PNAS, J. Am. Chem. Soc., Nat. Commun., Angew. Chem. Int. Ed., Sci. Bull., Energy Environ. Sci., with several of them are ranked as highly cited papers. She serves actively as a referee for journals in ACS, Wiley, RSC, Science Direct, and several Chinese journals.

coredata.dc:description: Fe-N-C based single-atom catalysts (SACs) with isolated Fe atoms dispersed on nitrogen-doped carbon matrix have achieved sustained attention for oxygen reduction reaction due to their great potential in replacing the Pt based noble catalysts in terms of catalytic activity. To further trigger the intrinsic activity of Fe-N-C, Fe based dual-atom catalysts (DACs, i.e., Fe-M-N-C) have been intensively studied, which confer the catalysts with readily tunable geometric configurations, electronic structures, thereby tailored catalytic properties. In this review, current progress on the rational design of Fe-M-N-C based DACs for enhanced oxygen reduction catalysis is summarized. Firstly, the ORR mechanisms on DACs are discussed where the second metal atoms can function through synergistic effect and/or modulation effect to promote the intrinsic catalytic activity. Moreover, the currently available synthetic approaches, characterization techniques and computational methods are systematically reviewed to aid the investigation of DACs. Then, DACs are classified into marriage-type and conjunct-type based on the interaction between metal atoms, whose properties are discussed at length with the atomic configuration. At last, the main challenges of Fe-M-N-C based DACs are summarized and some appealing directions towards highly efficient and stable energy applications are provided for their further enhancement.
